#Text=Interview : University of Guam 's Ron McNinch on North Korea 's nuclear threats
#Text=Monday , April 1 , 2013

#Text=With North Korea talking about nuclear weapons which may be capable of reaching the United States territory of Guam , Wikinews interviewed Dr. Ron McNinch , a specialist in East Asian governments , and the chair of Public Administration and Legal Studies at the University of Guam , to learn more about the impact of the latest news on the island .
#Text=An aerial view of Guam
#Text=Image : [ NASA 's Earth Observatory http://www.flickr.com/photos/nasaearthobservatory/ ] .
#Text=Is the current North Korean threat to Guam and other United States holdings in the Pacific
#Text=one which is treated as a credible threat of potential nuclear action by the Guamanian and United States government ?

#Text=Threats from a location such as North Korea should always be taken seriously , but to be frank , if North Korea wanted to attack the United States , there are far higher priority targets than Guam .
#Text=Also , if North Korea is considering an attack , it is much more likely in the form of cyber or special operations disruptions , rather than nuclear strikes .
#Text=Once a nation uses nuclear weapons , they lose the value of the weapon .
#Text=It is the threat the weapon holds that expresses power , not using it .
#Text=Has the current North Korean threat to Guam impacted the daily lives of people living on Guam ?
#Text=Do the locals take it seriously ?
#Text=In my own assessment of the social effects of this rhetoric , the people of Guam use a pragmatic approach based around typhoon preparation .
#Text=We prepare of course , but to be frank , the North Korean sabre-rattling last week was drowned out by small children on easter egg hunts and holiday barbeques with beer .
#Text=In the Marianas Variety April 1 edition , the threat was lampooned by the editors .
#Text=This parody could readily sum up the effects of the North Korean threats .
#Text=[ See external links , Ed ]
#Text=Is there potentially economic consequences for Guam as a result of this in terms of tourism dollars or the United States military presence changing ?
#Text=Our main tourism markets are Japan and Korea , both of which are under the same guns , no pun intended .
#Text=Therefore , it will not likely affect our tourism .
#Text=The US military presence is a form of stable tourism-like dollars and the effect of the military build up is best expressed in those terms .
#Text=In terms of Guam , how does this latest situation differ from past situations where North Korea has engaged in saber rattling ?
#Text=The difference this time is that North Korea claim to have or might have missles that can reach Guam .
#Text=What do you think will likely happen regarding North Korea in the coming weeks and months ?
#Text=Usually , North Korea engages in this sort of behavior when it feels that the international community is ignoring it .
#Text=Therefore , this rhetoric will likely ratchet down once China tells them to back off .
#Text=This is a common pattern in the past .
#Text=This bad behavior affects China more than the United States .
#Text=What do you think of the how the current situation with North Korea has evolved to date ?
#Text=The problem with this current rhetoric is that the movie " Olympus has Fallen , " which describes a North Korean action in Washington DC .
#Text=The real threat from North Korea is the unconventional warfare techniques that they can use on US soil , not convention or nuclear threats .
#Text=Disrupting basic power , water , medical or transportation services is a far greater threat than a nuclear threat .
